componenttextpreview: Yes, we would hope to hear from them within the next two weeks, correct.
componenttext: Yes, we would hope to hear from them within the next two weeks, correct.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Winfried Fruehauf with Winfried Fruehauf Consulting.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Winfried Fruehauf with Winfried Fruehauf Consulting.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Are there any synergies between BP's Montney properties that you're acquiring and your Horn River properties? And if they are, will the acquisition affect, in any way, the planned development of your Horn River project?
componenttext: Are there any synergies between BP's Montney properties that you're acquiring and your Horn River properties? And if they are, will the acquisition affect, in any way, the planned development of your Horn River project?

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: No, it really shouldn't. The Horn River is quite a bit further up to the northwest. The one thing that both the Noel and the Montney give us is some alternatives for our Kitimat project. We're continuing to exploit our Horn River, and we've got a number o
componenttext: No, it really shouldn't. The Horn River is quite a bit further up to the northwest. The one thing that both the Noel and the Montney give us is some alternatives for our Kitimat project. We're continuing to exploit our Horn River, and we've got a number of drills. We've got a plan this year, and we'll have a plan next year. But in terms of a long-term outlook supplying gas to Kitimat because of the logistics of where the Montney is, it could give us an alternative of taking gas west as opposed to taking it south and east.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And by that, do you mean that production from the Montney could enhance the amount of gas that you're planning to move out of the Horn River region?
componenttext: And by that, do you mean that production from the Montney could enhance the amount of gas that you're planning to move out of the Horn River region?

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Could enhance it or could it restrict it? I didn't quite understand your question.
componenttext: Could enhance it or could it restrict it? I didn't quite understand your question.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I should have said would it add potentially to the supply of Horn River gas?
componenttext: I should have said would it add potentially to the supply of Horn River gas?

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it could. It will be an incremental add.
componenttext: Yes, it could. It will be an incremental add.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I may be a little off topic from the acquisition. But can you give us a general update on any activities on the Granite Wash?
componenttext: I may be a little off topic from the acquisition. But can you give us a general update on any activities on the Granite Wash?

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we have John Crum sitting here. We've got six rigs running, John?
componenttext: Well, we have John Crum sitting here. We've got six rigs running, John?

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: We have eight rigs running on the Granite Wash and two more on the way. It's obviously pretty active, very porous and we've had good results to date. The one catch that I'll tell you is getting access to frac equipment has been somewhat difficult and that
componenttext: We have eight rigs running on the Granite Wash and two more on the way. It's obviously pretty active, very porous and we've had good results to date. The one catch that I'll tell you is getting access to frac equipment has been somewhat difficult and that's delayed some of our ramp up a little more than we would have liked, but feeling real good about the gain and we're continuing that acreage in the play.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And we're projecting we'll be at $75 million a day out of Granite Wash by the end of the year.
componenttext: And we're projecting we'll be at $75 million a day out of Granite Wash by the end of the year.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just taking a step back from a macro perspective with the combination of joint ventures that we've seen, and then your still buying under capitalized properties, and likely increasing activity in the North American onshore from the majors, how ar
componenttext: And then just taking a step back from a macro perspective with the combination of joint ventures that we've seen, and then your still buying under capitalized properties, and likely increasing activity in the North American onshore from the majors, how are you thinking about both the macro environment for both natural gas and NGLs here?

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I continue to think that we have an awful lot of gas in this country, which is a little bit of my statement earlier today. I think you have in the areas that you can buy gas at this price, you're better much off. And I don't mean its' bad, but buyin
componenttext: Well, I continue to think that we have an awful lot of gas in this country, which is a little bit of my statement earlier today. I think you have in the areas that you can buy gas at this price, you're better much off. And I don't mean its' bad, but buying gas two or three years ago, not on like what we did with Pioneer when we bought them out of Argentina, frankly, but we're seeing $4 and $5 gas prices in Argentina today. And I think over time, this country will go -- will have to transfer to natural gas. I think that's a foregone conclusion whether this administration accept that or not. We're going to use natural gas in this country for a long time. And we're a long-term believer in natural gas as an American, and as a producer, exactly. In terms of what the outlook for natural gas prices are, if you look at that strip, I think that is probably indicative of what you're going to see. I think we've seen the high prices out of it, and we've seen more prices, and I think we're starting to get an equilibrium.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from David Tameron with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from David Tameron with Wells Fargo.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Does it matter how these $7 billion that are allocated from your perspective -- is there anything as it relates to production sharing agreements? Any color you can give me there?
componenttext: Does it matter how these $7 billion that are allocated from your perspective -- is there anything as it relates to production sharing agreements? Any color you can give me there?

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: No, I mean we put on there the way we saw them in terms of values. In terms of long-term upside, I think, honestly, they all bring something different to the table. If you look at the Permian, in the past, we focused on the Oil side, and the reason is, is
componenttext: No, I mean we put on there the way we saw them in terms of values. In terms of long-term upside, I think, honestly, they all bring something different to the table. If you look at the Permian, in the past, we focused on the Oil side, and the reason is, is because oil was at $80 a barrel. We'll continue to do that. One of the reasons that we decided at the beginning of the year to hold them off was out there long before we had dreams of where we would be today. We've really focused on some of our water plus. We've been very successful in drilling horizontal wells in there. We think we've got a whole program of drilling horizontal wells and old water field. We drilled six to date, John? Six to date, all of them are tremendously economic. The best ones are doing 300 barrels a day. And I will tell you, at 300 barrels a day, you can make a hell of a lot of money and we know how much water you have to move. But each one of these areas bring something different. In Canada, we have an awful lot of vintage wells. I will tell you, out of this package, probably next year sometime, will come a rationalization package out of Canada, because we have a lot of stuff, smaller stuff in Alberta that we'll probably decide it doesn't fit our portfolio. I mean, we'll just have to wait when we get there and see.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Specific to Permian, you mentioned the tightness in the granite wash, obviously, Bakken, Haynesville, Eagle Ford, everything seems to be tight. What are you seeing on the Permian as far as rig availability, frac crews, et cetera?
componenttext: Specific to Permian, you mentioned the tightness in the granite wash, obviously, Bakken, Haynesville, Eagle Ford, everything seems to be tight. What are you seeing on the Permian as far as rig availability, frac crews, et cetera?

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the same issue still applies. Frac crews tend to be a little bit tight. We're seeing service companies that are not bringing some of their entire frac fleet on board. It's probably because it's going to require them to hire some more people,
componenttext: Yes, I think the same issue still applies. Frac crews tend to be a little bit tight. We're seeing service companies that are not bringing some of their entire frac fleet on board. It's probably because it's going to require them to hire some more people, and they just went though a down cycle last year. So how long it takes to bring them out of that, I don't know for sure. And I guess the other piece though you should keep in mind is we're not drilling a well, and then we're frac-ing at eight or 10 times. So we got a lot more use of the frac crews on a per well basis than we used to.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: No real problem on rigs.
componenttext: No real problem on rigs.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Ray Deacon with Pritchard Capital.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Ray Deacon with Pritchard Capital.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I just had a question about the $300 million of CapEx on the properties you're acquiring. Will those be primarily -- I guess, does that assume sort of a current run rate of activity, or will there be an increase in...
componenttext: I just had a question about the $300 million of CapEx on the properties you're acquiring. Will those be primarily -- I guess, does that assume sort of a current run rate of activity, or will there be an increase in...

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: No, I'll try to re-emphasize that. The $300 million is simply what we put in this acquisition when we evaluated. But I don't want to give the impression that will be how much money we spent on these properties next year. What it was is the way that the ev
componenttext: No, I'll try to re-emphasize that. The $300 million is simply what we put in this acquisition when we evaluated. But I don't want to give the impression that will be how much money we spent on these properties next year. What it was is the way that the evaluation was put together in terms of the value that we delivered to BP, not in terms of the value that we see for Apache going forward. Because I would hope we'll be spending multiples of that on these properties over the next several years.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: So I'd add to that, if you think back to Steve's comments about per share on earnings, slightly accretive to production per share, reserves per share and cash flow, basically, we're overlaying a major's plan for capital on our own. So we haven't kind of a
componenttext: So I'd add to that, if you think back to Steve's comments about per share on earnings, slightly accretive to production per share, reserves per share and cash flow, basically, we're overlaying a major's plan for capital on our own. So we haven't kind of applied the Apache magic or whatever you want to call it to these properties. The fact that they are happy with their cash flow, if you will, with $400 million, and you can perhaps double that for the whole year. And yet, the capital expenditures are only $300 million is pretty indicative of what kind of lack of investments that there was for these properties. So I think what we all sense here at Apache is that there's a lot of potential to do on these properties what we've done repeatedly on other packages from majors in the past, and that is add value by doing workovers, recompletions and exploration.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And the other thing, it's a little bit like -- I'm going to bring up a field that we bought from BP several years ago. It's called Forties. And obviously, it's in the water, and it's in a different part of the world. But when we bought that, we evaluated
componenttext: And the other thing, it's a little bit like -- I'm going to bring up a field that we bought from BP several years ago. It's called Forties. And obviously, it's in the water, and it's in a different part of the world. But when we bought that, we evaluated 146 million barrels. In March of this year, we produced 146 million barrels since we bought it. We have 175 million barrels of proved reserves on the books, and we're producing 68,000 barrels of oil a day. And the point is that it's not that BP didn't recognize that. In the field studies that we've had the opportunity to look at within BP, they have tremendous amount of opportunities. They've indicated they have risked resource of about 1.6 billion barrels on these properties. That was a BP estimate. We're not making any indication that, that's what we believe, but my point is they have worked these properties. Their individual people are not unlike what we saw in Forties. They had a lot of good ideas. They just couldn't get funded, and we're going to take their ideas and our ideas, and we're going to fund them, which is going to give us, hopefully, it's going to give an opportunity to really accelerate not only in what we bought but also to buy new stuff.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about Egypt or the targets there and your 2P, 3P numbers, are they primarily gas? Is that fair?
componenttext: Can you talk about Egypt or the targets there and your 2P, 3P numbers, are they primarily gas? Is that fair?

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, they're both. If you look at that little chart, that shale is the BED field and the Vega field in there, both of those are high gas condensate, basically. They produce a lot of gas, but they also produce a tremendous amount of liquid. Not unlike
componenttext: Actually, they're both. If you look at that little chart, that shale is the BED field and the Vega field in there, both of those are high gas condensate, basically. They produce a lot of gas, but they also produce a tremendous amount of liquid. Not unlike what we're seeing in the Jurassic. Both of those fields are out of the Jurassic. And it's interesting because in Europe -- in the appendix, you will see an outline of the different play types, the Baharia and the Cretaceous and lower Cretaceous AEB and then the Jurassic. But that area right circling that is very, very rich source rock. It's a big hole out there, really, and what you're doing is coming out of that hole, out of that base and up on to the platform. But you get oil from 6,500 feet to 15,000, 16,000 feet in that area. It's really a very prolific area. I mean, and hopefully, we'll be able to show you that over time, but that's a beautiful area from a geologic standpoint.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Rodney want to comment in what's the deck of those properties for a number of years.
componenttext: Rodney want to comment in what's the deck of those properties for a number of years.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: All right, these properties are -- commercially, a hundred of explorers, deeper horizon that is below the traditional phase in the Baharia and the Kharita, and the other line formations, there's been a storm out of oil production associated with these dev
componenttext: All right, these properties are -- commercially, a hundred of explorers, deeper horizon that is below the traditional phase in the Baharia and the Kharita, and the other line formations, there's been a storm out of oil production associated with these development places as well as gas. There are good water drilling opportunities we established, which is probably we're doing on one of the development places, but no project was done into full scale development, so there's good opportunities from that. Set in a recovery, lots of infill drilling potential, down spacing of some of the fields and [indiscernible] in the Baharia formation that provide multiple exploitation opportunities as well.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And I can't over emphasize. One of the problems with that slide, if we had 400,000 acres in the Permian Basin, everybody go, god, you got 400,000 acres. But because of our already existing position out there, it doesn't look very big. But that's a huge ar
componenttext: And I can't over emphasize. One of the problems with that slide, if we had 400,000 acres in the Permian Basin, everybody go, god, you got 400,000 acres. But because of our already existing position out there, it doesn't look very big. But that's a huge area, those little red areas is a huge area.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And another thing that's interesting about Egypt is as most of you know, we found so much gas there that we filled up the infrastructure and the rest of the desert, and Steve alluded to this. But they've got a gas line that you can see on that chart that
componenttext: And another thing that's interesting about Egypt is as most of you know, we found so much gas there that we filled up the infrastructure and the rest of the desert, and Steve alluded to this. But they've got a gas line that you can see on that chart that is underutilized that got $100 million a day of capacity. We've got more than $100 million a day bottled up waiting for structure. So that's something that our guys are going to look very closely at and quickly, and we hope to bring that online before too long.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Joe Magner of Macquarie.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Joe Magner of Macquarie.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: You haven't had just much in the past. Do you expect to revisit that strategy going forward now that you're layering on these volumes, and with some of the recent transactions that are still pending?
componenttext: You haven't had just much in the past. Do you expect to revisit that strategy going forward now that you're layering on these volumes, and with some of the recent transactions that are still pending?

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the first thing I'd say is we've got authorization to hedge, and we've got some time to think it through, because these things are closing over a period of a month. But I think Steve kind of indicated what our thoughts are with respect to hedging, a
componenttext: Well, the first thing I'd say is we've got authorization to hedge, and we've got some time to think it through, because these things are closing over a period of a month. But I think Steve kind of indicated what our thoughts are with respect to hedging, and we are basically dormant on the acquisition front while gas is at $7, $8, $9, $10 an MCF. Now that we're down to these levels, where gas on a strip and what we're using as a value of these properties is going to rise about $6 for basically five years. We think a lot of the downside has already been taking out by the market. So we don't feel compelled at these prices to rush out there and hedge. That having been said, we'll take a look. And as time goes by, but at least at this point, we have no plans to hedge the gas, and 2/3 of the production is gas. So that's really the relevant commodity in this instance.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I might have missed this, but the 364-day bank facility and the commercial paper balance, do you plan to generate enough free cash flow the next year or so to pay those down? Would that be the plan?
componenttext: I might have missed this, but the 364-day bank facility and the commercial paper balance, do you plan to generate enough free cash flow the next year or so to pay those down? Would that be the plan?

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I think we are going to talk about -- we've been schooled that we can't talk about the financing and the payment offerings until tomorrow. So if you can hold that question until tomorrow when we get in Boston, New York and San Francisco, we'll have a bett
componenttext: I think we are going to talk about -- we've been schooled that we can't talk about the financing and the payment offerings until tomorrow. So if you can hold that question until tomorrow when we get in Boston, New York and San Francisco, we'll have a better picture of that for you.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just in the Gulf of Mexico, it looks like you were one of the first to receive a permit and are drilling on the shelf. Can you give us an update on what you're hearing or seeing with respect to the permitting process out there?
componenttext: And then just in the Gulf of Mexico, it looks like you were one of the first to receive a permit and are drilling on the shelf. Can you give us an update on what you're hearing or seeing with respect to the permitting process out there?

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: We are starting to get some permits through, but it continues to be slow. The MMS boe are still going through some teething problems in getting setup with their new organization as you can imagine. So we're expecting delays in virtually everything, but we
componenttext: We are starting to get some permits through, but it continues to be slow. The MMS boe are still going through some teething problems in getting setup with their new organization as you can imagine. So we're expecting delays in virtually everything, but we are able to move forward on our Gulf of Mexico program that the Apache itself had. The Mariner piece is still being held up on a number of fronts, and we're just hoping for near term success, but still some holdups.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure who best to address, but some interesting proposals coming out of Washington these days on some policy and regulatory fronts on the heels, not just dealing with the Gulf of Mexico, but also some things impacting onshore. Can you just give us
componenttext: I'm not sure who best to address, but some interesting proposals coming out of Washington these days on some policy and regulatory fronts on the heels, not just dealing with the Gulf of Mexico, but also some things impacting onshore. Can you just give us your thoughts on how any of those proposals might affect doing business here in the states going forward?

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, luckily, there's still proposals. I'd rather not comment, and the reason is, is that I think I'm a big believer that in the end, cool heads will prevail. Certainly, on the hydraulic fracturing front, Apache is a member of anger, and I happen to be o
componenttext: Well, luckily, there's still proposals. I'd rather not comment, and the reason is, is that I think I'm a big believer that in the end, cool heads will prevail. Certainly, on the hydraulic fracturing front, Apache is a member of anger, and I happen to be on that executive board of anger. There's been an awful lot of work and a lot of interaction with the people that are writing some of those barrels. At least, our expectation is, is that we'll get something reasonable out of that, but you can never be sure today.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Dave Kistler with Simmons & Co.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Dave Kistler with Simmons & Co.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Real quickly, in the Permian, do you mind sharing with us if you've drilled any Bone Springs or Avalon well?
componenttext: Real quickly, in the Permian, do you mind sharing with us if you've drilled any Bone Springs or Avalon well?

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: We haven't, but we've got a couple of Alberet wells ready to drill, and it will have some Bone Springs being drilled later this year.
componenttext: We haven't, but we've got a couple of Alberet wells ready to drill, and it will have some Bone Springs being drilled later this year.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And we have some acreage in there.  At Apache, we have acreage in there.
componenttext: And we have some acreage in there.  At Apache, we have acreage in there.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: At Apache, do you pick any with BP as well?
componenttext: At Apache, do you pick any with BP as well?

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. Well, a part of the real attraction of this play is Yeso out there in there in edge of the reef, but there's additional acreage in the Bone Springs and in Talbot.
componenttext: Absolutely. Well, a part of the real attraction of this play is Yeso out there in there in edge of the reef, but there's additional acreage in the Bone Springs and in Talbot.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: With respect to midstream assets that you're picking up, obviously, the exception that may be Egypt -- are those things that you would be looking at monetizing at one point or another, or is the intention to hold onto those, just because it's strategicall
componenttext: With respect to midstream assets that you're picking up, obviously, the exception that may be Egypt -- are those things that you would be looking at monetizing at one point or another, or is the intention to hold onto those, just because it's strategically, advantage of you and make it a high liquids market, who knows what?

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the one in Egypt is we've been coveting since 1997. So it's going to be in a very strategic integral part of our plans in Egypt. And the ones in the Permian Basin are both very integral to the liquids, and the yield associated with our production th
componenttext: Well, the one in Egypt is we've been coveting since 1997. So it's going to be in a very strategic integral part of our plans in Egypt. And the ones in the Permian Basin are both very integral to the liquids, and the yield associated with our production there. So those are strategic in that regard. In Canada, we're just dying to look at. I doubt if we sell or monetize any of those plans.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, they're probably modest plants in Canada as a general rule, and really serving and producing assets through there.
componenttext: Yes, they're probably modest plants in Canada as a general rule, and really serving and producing assets through there.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Philip Rodge (sic) [Philip Dodge] with Tuohy Brothers.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Philip Rodge (sic) [Philip Dodge] with Tuohy Brothers.

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Going back to Egypt, at the June meeting, you set a five-year target of increasing your production there, 50%, as I recall. Would it be fair in our work to assume that you might be able to exceed that now, or this kind of transaction or something like it'
componenttext: Going back to Egypt, at the June meeting, you set a five-year target of increasing your production there, 50%, as I recall. Would it be fair in our work to assume that you might be able to exceed that now, or this kind of transaction or something like it's on track again for that goal?

headline: Apache Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we set the goal of June 16 with our analyst meeting after achieving our two times production plan for 2005 and doubling our production at 332,000 barrels a day. We announced that meeting. We've set a goal for ourself 100,000 barrels a day gross prod
componenttext: Well, we set the goal of June 16 with our analyst meeting after achieving our two times production plan for 2005 and doubling our production at 332,000 barrels a day. We announced that meeting. We've set a goal for ourself 100,000 barrels a day gross production to 425,000 barrels a day in a maximum five-year period. At that time, of course, this transaction is not envisioned as we have to incorporate better and make plans. So I'd say based on this acquisition, we certainly have a better chance of achieving and exceeding that goal instead of revising it accordingly.

componenttext: Well, all of these assets, one of the things in our history is that Apache has been very acquisitive. Certainly, the Egyptians' assets have fit us for a number of years. And the Permian assets and the Canadian assets -- certainly, the Permian assets was not the first time we've had that discussion. And in Canada, it is really the outcrop of what we've been doing out there lately in terms of the Horn River and that kind of stuff. It really gives us an opportunity really to exploit those properties. So in terms of the Deepwater, it was never discussed.

componenttext: Well, I think that's been discussed, and I think the industry has proposals whereby maybe there'd be a, in effect, a sinking fund, so that the tax we pay or used to pay as an industry on all barrels produced in the U.S. to fund the environmental fund, if you will, after the Valdez. There's now proposals that the amount per barrel be increased modestly, but it's not enough barrels that it would back up pretty rapidly. Until that slum goes from my recollection, about $1.5 billion to $10 billion. In effect, it would be like an insurance fund, if you will.

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Apache Corporation Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Release. Today's presentation will be hosted by Mr. Tom Chambers, Vice President of Corporate Planning and Investor Relations. Mr. Chambers, please go ahead.
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Apache Corporation Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Release. Today's presentation will be hosted by Mr. Tom Chambers, Vice President of Corporate Planning and Investor Relations. Mr. Chambers, please go ahead.

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone and thanks for joining us for Apache Corporation's Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. This morning, we reported net income of $765 million or $2.12 per diluted share. Adjusted earnings, which exclude certain i
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone and thanks for joining us for Apache Corporation's Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. This morning, we reported net income of $765 million or $2.12 per diluted share. Adjusted earnings, which exclude certain items that impact the comparability of results totaled $791 million or $2.19 per diluted share. Cash flow from operations totaled $2 billion. 
On today's call, we'll have four speakers making prepared remarks prior to taking questions. Steve Farris, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer will lead off followed by Roger Plank, our President; John Crum, Co-Chief Operating Officer and President, North America; and then Rod Eichler, Co-Chief Operating Officer and President of International. 
We prepared our usual detailed supplemental data package for your use, which also includes the reconciliation of any non-GAAP numbers that we discussed, such as adjusted earnings, cash flow from operations or costs incurred. This data package can be found on our website at www.apachecorp.com/financialdata
Today's discussions may contain forward-looking estimates and assumptions and no assurances can be given that those expectations will be realized. A full disclaimer is located with the supplemental data package on our website. With that I'll turn the call over to Steve.

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom and good afternoon, everyone and thank all of you for joining us for our third quarter 2010 results call. Those of you who have followed us for many years know that Apache has a truly unique culture and is involved with strong sense of urge
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom and good afternoon, everyone and thank all of you for joining us for our third quarter 2010 results call. Those of you who have followed us for many years know that Apache has a truly unique culture and is involved with strong sense of urgency and paramount of our employees and an independent mindset. And Apache's culture really is that the heart of how we build value and has taken us from very humble position not so long ago to where we are today. And I don't think there's anything that exemplifies more our third quarter, what that culture is capable of delivering for our shareholders. 
On the portfolio side, we announced the $7 billion acquisition of three entire upstream operating regions from BP and the Permian Basin, Canada and Egypt. These three positions have an excellent fit with our existing carriers and provide us with a rich inventory of growth and value enhancement opportunity for years to come. 
It was July 20, the last conference call, we were just announcing this step, and we were getting ready to get on a plane to go sell stock and debt for this important step forward. And while we clearly believed that the transaction had all the ingredients to make a great deal for our shareholders, we really didn't know how the share price would react, given the amount of new stock we were about to issue. 
Well, as most of you know, the stock actually went up by 5% in the three days after we announced, and this is opposite of what generally happens. Internally, we took that as an endorsement of Apache's ability to generate value out of the transaction. Obviously, we're honored with the vote of confidence. I want to ensure all of you, we'll do everything humanly possible to make good on this investment, to create long-term value for our shareholders. As of about an hour ago, we have now closed all three of the BP packages, if you haven't looked at the Wire, we just closed Egypt today. But we are integrating the people and starting to get our arms around the assets.  In addition, we expect to close on our merger with Mariner Energy when the vote ends on November 10.
We couldn't be more pleased and excited about the opportunity set we are building into our portfolio with the $11 billion in acquisitions. Through these steps we have added years of inventory to our core regions and have built the right footprint in what we believe are two new areas for us, the Deepwater oil exploration and LNG. LNG, for us, means the monetization of large North American gas resources at oil length prices. 
We've taken these steps on our own way which is the Apache way and we're confident that we'll constitute important foundations for Apache's continued growth and profitability during the coming decade. 
On the operating front, in the third quarter, we had a very successful quarter, with production was up 10% year-on-year and our cost and expense is on a per unit basis, excluding DD&A, it was down 3% year-on-year. John, Rod and Roger will give you more color on our results and developments during the quarter in a moment. Before getting to that, I'd like to put 2010 in a broader context, starting with where we were at the beginning of 2010 and what we look like going into 2011. 
If you recall, in February of this year on our 2009 year-end conference call, we were very bullish on what we've received in the acquisition market. We had amassed over $2 billion of cash on the balance sheet, and with commodity prices at more reasonable levels, we indicated that we would be very actively pursuing acquisition opportunity. Little did we know how attractive it would become. After the dust settles, and we have closed on all $11 billion of assets, apache's share count would have increased by approximately 12%, and we project we will end the year with a debt to cap of under 27%. 
Now on the flip side, on the production side, we are projecting December 2010 average production to exceed 775,000 barrels of oil equivalent a day. So if you use the first quarter 2010 as a baseline, when Apache's production averaged 586,000 barrels of oil equivalent, we're entering 2011 with a third more firepower than we entered 2010. That added firepower will give us more cash flow to exploit the 3.8 million acres we acquired across three of the most prolific core areas Canada, Permian and Western Desert of Egypt. And the new core areas we've added in deepwater Gulf of Mexico has over 125 undeveloped blocks and interest in two world-class discoveries in Lucius and Heidelberg.   
Obviously, we're extremely excited about what we've been able to add to what we consider an already formative base and the opportunity that they bring to continue to add long-term value to our shareholders. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Roger, John and Rod to talk about 2010 and '11 in a little more detail. Roger?

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Steve, and good afternoon, everyone. Steve commented about how 2010 is shaping up and in a minute, I'm going to give a further glimpse of what may be a truly outstanding 2011. But before delving into next year I'd like to provide a few key h
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Steve, and good afternoon, everyone. Steve commented about how 2010 is shaping up and in a minute, I'm going to give a further glimpse of what may be a truly outstanding 2011. But before delving into next year I'd like to provide a few key highlights, financial highlights to the current quarter results. We think we have fine results, even though there were a lot of moving parts with all these transactions closing. 
Production was up 3% over second quarter to a record 667,000 barrels of oil equivalent. Oil and liquids were, once again the kind, representing just over half our production, but over 3/4 of our revenue. Cash costs per boe were essentially flat with second quarter while DD&A was up 3% as you might expect, given that our acquisitions remain at prices above our historic reserve cost. 
Debt ended at $6.5 billion and debt to cap at 23%, and that excludes $1.2 billion of cash on the books at quarter's end. Also, just of our year of acquisitions doesn't overshadow the considerable progress we're making on the organic side of our business. You should know that from the first quarter to the third, our oil production jumped 17% or 48,000 barrels per day, and over 3/4 of that growth was attributable solely to drilling and development activities, primarily in Egypt and especially, Australia. 
Turning to 2011. We're just now in the early stage of the part of next year's plan, but one thing seems certain, our year-over-year production growth should be well into the double digit. Exactly how much our production growth depends on our ultimate capital budget, which will be fine tuned between now and the year end. Our preliminary however, our capital budget is likely to reach or exceed $7 billion, up from around $6 billion this year and well within cash flow at prices currently indicated for next year. 
We've hedged oil for 2011 to protect cash flow and it's current active capital campaign. While we believe that the supply and demand outlook strongly favors oil, with over 3/4 of our revenue tied to oil and liquids since last quarter, we've hedged 64,000 barrels per day for 2011. We used costless collars with floors between $65 to $70 to protect the downside and ceilings between $95 to $103 to retain upside potential. We now have about 100,000 barrels per day hedged in total for 2011 or just over 1/4 of our post-merger liquids production. 
In addition to ensuring sufficient cash flow and capital to get after the upside on recently acquired properties, we are focusing particular attention on our extensive inventory of oil and liquids prospect for next year. I can't tell you how nice it is to have a deep inventory of oil prospects already enhanced and not have to join the herd chasing after high-cost oil opportunities after essentially the train's already left the station. 
I would like not to hedge any additional North American gases at today's low prices. And we are continuing to focus capital on those international gas projects, which are commanding substantially higher prices. Everyday oil remains at this lumpy level since more debt reduction than earlier anticipated. Additionally, to ensure that we make a major dent in our debt, which should peak following the Mariner merger at over $8 billion, we anticipate selling $1 billion of property sometime in the first half of 2011. We're just now in the process of determining which properties we'll be selling. So it's a bit early to tell the precise location, timing and impact of those sales. 
The combination of high oil prices and property sales meant lower debt and greater financial flexibility, consistent with an A-rated company. With double-digit production growth pretty much a shoo-in for 2011, a portfolio that's low in oil, a deep inventory of drilling opportunities and a strong financial position, we look forward to what could prove to be a better year in 2011. John?

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Roger. Our third quarter North American activity has been dominated by the efforts associated with the integration of more than $10 billion in assets, being added to our portfolio this year. We closed the BP Permian transaction in the third qua
componenttext:
Thank you, Roger. Our third quarter North American activity has been dominated by the efforts associated with the integration of more than $10 billion in assets, being added to our portfolio this year. We closed the BP Permian transaction in the third quarter and the Canadian piece closed in early October. We took over operations in the BP Canada properties on Monday of this week and welcomed almost 300 new Apaches. We will take over the BP Permian assets December 1, meanwhile, we expect to close on the Mariner merger next week after their shareholder meeting on November 10. 
Third quarter North American production was up over 7% versus second quarter to just under 309,000 barrels equivalent per day. Fourth quarter volumes will be up substantially as we see the impact of BP and Mariner acquisitions. 
Gulf Coast production increased 7% from the second quarter. Drilling activity offshore continues to be severely impacted by the permitting process associated with post and conduit requirements. While our Gulf region has received seven of the first 12 permits given to the Gulf of Mexico, requiring both NTL-05 and NTL-06 compliance. They remain significantly behind the plans for the year. 
At least for now the lack of clarity on the process makes it difficult for the BOEM [Bureau of Ocean Energy Management] to approve anything in a timely fashion. We are however, presently running five jack-up rigs and one platform rig offshore, drilling primarily for oil targets. With permitting delays resolved, we expect to have a very strong 2011 drilling program with the addition of the new assets from Devon and Mariner. 
Our third quarter project of note is the redevelopment of the hurricane-damaged Eugene Island 330 field now underway. Three wells have already been drilled and are expected to add some 2,000 barrels a day, with additional drilling to extend into mid-2011 on the 63% working interest field. 
In the Permian region, we increased production by 21% on partial quarter BP volumes at a very active drilling program. Permian region production is expected to be up again on the fourth quarter as core BP volumes and the Mariner assets are added in. The BP and Mariner transactions allow our newly formed Permian region to add substantially to an already robust oil Permian drilling inventory with at least 3,000 new identified locations. The region was already very active in the quarter with seven rigs, drilling 73 new wells, while 116 wells were completed as we caught up on a backlog of frac stimulation work. 
With the addition of the Mariner properties later this month, we expect to keep up the 20 rigs running in the Permian for 2011. We also reached agreement with Concho on the BP, more above the Yeso play in New Mexico. Apache acquired a 60% working interest in the operatorship of the joint properties. We have identified 800 drillable locations in the play and expect to be very active there next year. 
The region continues to evaluate horizontal drilling potentials in a variety of well known producing intervals in the basin. We continue to have success with horizontal completions in all water fluid operations notably North McElroy in the Grayburg formation, TXL South in the Clearfork and Shafter Lake in the San Andres, where we're seeing IPs in the 250 to 400 barrel a day range.
The Central region also increased production by 7% from the second quarter. Importantly, distribution and gas coverage was up almost 20% on their oil productions. The region activity continues to be dominated by horizontal multi-stage frac operations in the liquid-rich Granite Wash play in Western Oklahoma and the Texas Panhandle. 
We expect to drill 40 horizontal Granite Wash wells this year. The first 19 are currently on production and producing a net of 2,600 barrels of oil a day and some 40 million feet of gas. As in the Permian, we continue to look for additional applications for horizontal drilling. With this in mind, we recently test what we believe to be the first horizontal test on the of the Hogshooter Wash interval of the Granite Wash play.  
This morning, we announced two very successful tests. Each well produced the initial rates of over 2,000 barrels of oil a day and continue to average more than 700 barrels a day and 3.5 million feet of gas after two months. We expect to drill 10 additional Hogshooter tests in 2011. 
Our Canada region production decreased 1.8% from the second quarter. That figure will be up substantially in the fourth quarter as we add in BP volumes and ramp up at Horn River. Our 50%-owned Horn River production continues to build and reach the 100 million per day gross raw gas milestone in August and is expected to reach 200 million per day by first quarter of 2011. 
We have 18 new wells on production in 2010 and expect to bring another 12 on during the remainder of the year. We will leave the year with 24 wells already drilled and awaiting completion. As mentioned earlier, our Canadian region is quickly integrating BP properties with the help of the 300 new Apaches who moved in last Monday. While it's a little crowded in our Calgary office, while we complete the space build out, we wanted to get the things together as soon as possible. 
The most notable operation in the BP asset base in Canada is the Noel field producing from the Cadomin and Doig intervals. In addition, the field appears to have significant modeling potential, for which testing is now underway. Noel field production is currently at 62 million cubic feet of gas per day and is expected to reach 96 million by the end of the year and 125 million by the second quarter of 2011. The region is especially excited about the strong drilling inventory and the multitude of workover recompletion opportunities that are available with the new BP acquisition. 
And now Rod Eichler will give you an update on international.

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Apache's international operations saw a good quarter, averaging 359,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, with production increasing in three out of the four countries of operation. Egypt's gross production increased 3% to 323,000 barr
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Apache's international operations saw a good quarter, averaging 359,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, with production increasing in three out of the four countries of operation. 
Egypt's gross production increased 3% to 323,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. Net production was only up slightly resulting from timing differences in the PSC cost recovery mechanism. New production from Faghur Basin fields and discoveries as well as from our mature development lease help push gross operated oil and gas production above the 300,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day mark for the third consecutive quarter. Phase 2 of the Faghur Basin infrastructure project designed to upgrade capacity to 40,000 barrels of oil per day was completed on schedule on September 30. 
The acquisition of BP's risk-rated assets is complete. All contracts and agreements have been finalized and the final approvement from the government of Egypt was received today, closing occurred about an hour ago. Upon assuming operatorship, in terms of pinging on the 24-inch Abu Gharadig to Dashur pipeline will commence and we expect it to be completed by year end. 
Minor modifications of the existing system will be completed during first quarter of 2011 that will allow high liquid yield gas from the Faghur Basin to bypass this long gas plant and be directed to our existing 18-inch southern pipeline in the newly acquired Abu Gharadig plant and onward to the national gas, we had at the 24-inch Abu Gharadig to Dashur pipeline. 
So on gas train five and the Southern Pipeline loop projects should commence in early 2011. FEED studies with both the gas plant and the pipeline expansion have been completed. Negotiations to enter into EPC contracts are expected to be completed in the first quarter with project completions forecast in late 2012. With the addition of the BP properties [ph] continued drilling success in the Faghur and the two basins and each production infrastructure improvements for 2011 drilling campaign is set to be a busy one, with the forecast number of exploratory and tests up over 50% compared to 2010 and total well count expected to exceed 200 gross wells. 
In Australia, net production decreased a modest 5% in second quarter. Gad production decreased due to lower customer nominations, while oil production decreased due to natural decline in the Van Gogh oilfield. Van Gogh had a 52.5% working interest, averaged 23,700 barrels of oil per day net during the quarter, and the field has produced 11.2 million barrels gross, since startup in February, achieving project pay out in late September. 
On October 4, we shut in Van Gogh production in and the shoved him back go production and the FPSO production seals in the swivel portion of a detachable DTM system were found to be leaking and no hydrocarbon or liquids will leak to the ocean.  The failure of all swivel seals at the same time is pretty much impressive, and it's not an event that could have been reasonably foreseen. The result is that we have gone from a total seal failure to restarting production in 19 days. The temporary repairs have restored partial production to approximately 2,500 barrels of oil per day gross.  Permanent repairs will allow Van Gogh to return to full production and 40,000 barrels of oil per day gross by mid-December. 
The BHP-operated Pyrenees FPSO development, in which Apache has a working interest that ranges from 28.5% to 31.5% continue to perform well in the third quarter, with net production averaging 23,600 barrels of oil per day, up 2,300 barrels per day on the second quarter. Total production from Pyrenees from start up through September 30 was 17.1 million barrels of oil gross. Pyrenees continues to believe in the steady 94,000 and 98,000 barrels of oil per day gross. 
Delta, Halyard and Devil Creek development projects remain on schedule to deliver first gas to the Western Australia domestic market in 2011. Halyard, in which Apache has a 5% working interest has a one-well tie back of the 2008 halyard gas discovery to our Varanus Island hub. First gas expected in May 2011. 
The Halyard project is designed for future well tie-ins expected at exploration success in the greater east far area. For example, Apache recently acquired a 55% in operatorship of the adjacent Spar field.  The Spar-2 appraisal well drilled in October found 163 feet of net gas play in the Upper Morrow objective. 
Upon testing and completion of this well, we've tied into the Halyard system. The Devil Creek development project and it's Apache has a 55% working interest, is 60% complete through September and are scheduled to deliver first gas from our Reindeer field by November of 2011.  Fabrication of the Reindeer Wellhead Platform is 90% and installation of the 16-inch onshore raw gas pipeline from the beach process to the gas plant has been. 
To expand our exploration drilling inventory in 2011 and beyond, we've acquired eight new blocks in the Carnarvon Basin via purchase of [indiscernible], getting over 10,000 square kilometers of new exploration acreage, thus increasing our total acreage position in the basin by 35. Apache will operate all eight blocks at average to the 52%. 4,600 square kilometers of new drilling site will be acquired in these blocks, starting in December of 2010. 
Australia continue to offer attractive gas prices for new long term domestic contracts for further existing products. In addition, we made progress in monetizing our Julimar gas, signed two separate hedge of agreement for 20-year supply of LNG at oil-linked prices. One of these agreement's with the Tokyo Electric and the other one is with KOGAS [Korea Gas Corporation].  We also continued to add growth to our pipeline with the sanction of the Macedon domestic gas development project and the successful appraisal of our 2009 oil discovery at Balnaves. 
In the North Sea, production was flat in the second quarter. Increased output from our drilling program is offset by planned downtime at Bravo and Charlie platforms, an active drilling program that continue in Forties during the third quarter. Two of the field's fields four platform rigs will be in continuous operation. In addition, by quarter end, the though jack up will begin a six-month drilling training campaign over the Echo platform. Drilling has not taken place in Echo since July of 2005. 
Our satellite platform bridge linked to the Alpha platform is progressing for installation in 2012. This project will allow expansion of critical utilities the field, including expanding power generation, fewer processing capacity, high-pressure gas impression, dehydration, and most importantly 18 new slots for drilling. 
During the quarter, a new time lapse or 4D seismic survey was completed in Forties, with fast-track process data, coming available in time to influence the drilling locations previously referenced to Echo. Seismic imaging has driven the majority of drilling success at Forties for the seven years. These data, along with additional drilling slots and for the Alpha satellite platform should enable Forties maintain steady production in the 60,000 barrel day range over the next three plus years. 
In Argentina net production is at 7% for the second quarter. Gas production increased 11% as a result of the successful 2010 gas plus drilling program in. Neuquen. The TDS, San Sebastian drilling program and the increase in the order demand. For the gas plus pricing program, we've signed one gas contract for 28 million feet gas per day in August 2010 with Pampa Energy and we expect to sign a second contract with Pampa to 25 million a day this month. 
These two contracts were effective January 1, 2011, and specify a $5 per million BTU gas price for three years. These contracts will go a long way in pulling up our basket price in Neuquen Basin of our $3 per million BTU. In support of these contracts Apache has 18 wells a day in two fields in Neuquen Basin, with production capacity of 47 million cubic feet of gas per day. Additional wells are currently drilling. And by January 1, 2011, Apache will have more than 53 million feet of gas per day available to satisfy these higher-prices gas contracts. 
That concludes our prepared remarks, and we'll now be happy to open up for questions.

componenttext: I wanted to see if you can give us an update on what you're seeing in the LNG markets in terms of willingness and maybe price sensitivity, the long-term contracts and then an update on how you're thinking about Kitimat?

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we were in a situation where we were really just gone out to the market because of our Wheatstone.  The Wheatstone 2 contracts that were signed was very important and we wanted to have that gas on the market before we really started to actively proc
componenttext: Well, we were in a situation where we were really just gone out to the market because of our Wheatstone.  The Wheatstone 2 contracts that were signed was very important and we wanted to have that gas on the market before we really started to actively procuring contracts at Kitimat. Right now, we're very early. Of course we have an awful lot of interest of potential buyers with one of our gas. I don't think that there's any question, and I hear it all the time. Is it going to be gas-related? There's a no projects in the world that are going to build an LNG-facility based on a gas price. It's going to have to be based on an oil price. And it's really too early to tell what that slope is going to look like, Brian.

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Separately in the Granite Wash, can you add a little bit more color regarding what zones you drilled and how you see the potential for further running room and in extent of the liquids content and the oil content that you saw with these two wells, extendi
componenttext: Separately in the Granite Wash, can you add a little bit more color regarding what zones you drilled and how you see the potential for further running room and in extent of the liquids content and the oil content that you saw with these two wells, extending to other parts of your acreage.

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Brian, obviously, this is first time we tested the Hogshooter in a horizontal fashion. So it was really good results. There tends to a little shy shower in the sequence, and obviously, as our liquid yields -- the issue, of course, is that, that extends ac
componenttext: Brian, obviously, this is first time we tested the Hogshooter in a horizontal fashion. So it was really good results. There tends to a little shy shower in the sequence, and obviously, as our liquid yields -- the issue, of course, is that, that extends across the entire acreage base. The good news is these wells are more than five miles apart, so it's not like this is an isolated area. We have some 200,000 acres we control in this play. So obviously, we'll be casting this with additional wells next year. We presently plan 10 Hogshooter intervals alone. We continue to test the additional intervals within the Granite Wash. That sequence can change anywhere from two to eight or so separate little sand intervals. And so we're going to continue to figure out where the best place to go with our future drillings. Obviously, it's liquids.

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: And what do you see with the current infrastructure? If there are any infrastructure constraints at what level of rig count you could take it up to as more of a capacity perspective? How aggressive could you ramp that up, if you want to next year?
componenttext: And what do you see with the current infrastructure? If there are any infrastructure constraints at what level of rig count you could take it up to as more of a capacity perspective? How aggressive could you ramp that up, if you want to next year?

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: The natural gas prices does have something to do with that. Obviously, these high liquid yields helps our economics substantially. But I think a lot of the infrastructure issues are associated with gas back outs and the bottom line is these kinds of price
componenttext: The natural gas prices does have something to do with that. Obviously, these high liquid yields helps our economics substantially. But I think a lot of the infrastructure issues are associated with gas back outs and the bottom line is these kinds of prices, conventional drilling's kind of dried up. So we haven't seen any real change. We would expect to run some Granite Wash rigs next year.

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Doug Leggate with Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Doug Leggate with Merrill Lynch.

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm wants to start off with the production guidance. On the production discussion, I guess, you had  a few minutes ago. If we just look at what you're saying about December, and let's assume we took Q3 as a flat rate for October,  November just as a start
componenttext: I'm wants to start off with the production guidance. On the production discussion, I guess, you had  a few minutes ago. If we just look at what you're saying about December, and let's assume we took Q3 as a flat rate for October,  November just as a starting point, and then run December for next year, assuming that new projets offset declines, I guess, you could have about 19% growth rate year-over-year. Am I smoking something, or is that in the ballpark? And then what, really, do you see as the key project moving parts for next year that could change that one way or the other?

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think your math is probably pretty correct, The real question obviously is, and it always is, and people don't want to hear this commodity price. Because you really got to have capital to put on these properties. And right now, frankly, we have ve
componenttext: Well, I think your math is probably pretty correct, The real question obviously is, and it always is, and people don't want to hear this commodity price. Because you really got to have capital to put on these properties. And right now, frankly, we have very good oil prices and I don't know whether the fed's buying treasury is going to help -- the bond market is going to help the economy, but it's damn sure helping the oil price. that's good news for us. the 50% of our production is on the oil side. The real question besides commodity prices is what we sell and when we sell it? We're dedicated to getting our debt to cap down and that is we're at below 27% at the end of the year. If we sold $1 billion, I mean, it would help us greatly to be down in the same category we were at the beginning of the year and we really haven't identified those properties yet. But we're going to have -- I mean, if you just look at the metrics, you're going to have good numbers next year, it's going to be hard not to frankly.

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Capital expenditure on the BP assets that you've acquired, could you identify what step up might be, I think, when you did the deal you suggested BP was something planning something like a $400 million, $500 million CapEx plan.  What would your numbers li
componenttext: Capital expenditure on the BP assets that you've acquired, could you identify what step up might be, I think, when you did the deal you suggested BP was something planning something like a $400 million, $500 million CapEx plan.  What would your numbers likely look like on those properties?

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: In fact well, all our Corporate Engineering Engineering Group and our planning group have just now made a loop to everyone in the regions, including the Permian and Canada. Quite frankly, John mentioned the Yeso play. I mean, we've identified 800 location
componenttext: In fact well, all our Corporate Engineering Engineering Group and our planning group have just now made a loop to everyone in the regions, including the Permian and Canada. Quite frankly, John mentioned the Yeso play. I mean, we've identified 800 locations. It's a question of how many rigs you want to run out there. This isn't a question of how much money could we spend. It's going to be will we spend in each one of these areas. Because, frankly, you could double that number in the Permian Basin right now. In terms of opportunity sets and the real issue is going to be how do we balance that portfolio. It's going to be one of our real strategic issues this year.

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to drill a little bit on a couple of specific assets. Egypt, first of all, so the pipeline looks like it's going to be taken care of next year. What is your latest thoughts in terms of how much of your 300 million a day, you're going to be a
componenttext: I just wanted to drill a little bit on a couple of specific assets. Egypt, first of all, so the pipeline looks like it's going to be taken care of next year. What is your latest thoughts in terms of how much of your 300 million a day, you're going to be able to open up. And finally, Mist Mountain,  you never really seem to talk about that too much. Any thoughts on the 8 million cubic feet asset that doesn't really seem to get much of a profile?

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: The first part, dealing with the $300 million a day, and this is referencing the shut in gas that we have on wells that have already been drilled and  completed in the called area. The existing pipeline, and I'm talking about the remote components to evac
componenttext: The first part, dealing with the $300 million a day, and this is referencing the shut in gas that we have on wells that have already been drilled and  completed in the called area. The existing pipeline, and I'm talking about the remote components to evacuate the gas to this new route. One is our Southern 18-inch gas pipeline, prices are in place for the last decade, and then to a short pipeline. That line is old and have been derated and is really carrying about 40 million to 45 million cubic feet of gas a day at present. Our expectation is to be able to add because the configuration of gas plants downstream, the gases are slightly different composition that we have in the northwestern part of desert. We're bringing the two gas down there. And it's our expectation as the pipeline pigs out, it can be rerated to it's original rating approximately 150 million a day that we should be able to add about 85 to perhaps 100 million a day into that line from Marmacu [ph] Basin fields sometime in 2011 that'll be incremental to the existing gas which is really down the line right now and bring it to its full capacity.

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: And on Mist Mountain point, obviously, that's coal bed methane in Southern Canada. We see that project needs a substantial amount of additional research and certainly consultation before we're able to move forward. And most importantly, it needs some high
componenttext: And on Mist Mountain point, obviously, that's coal bed methane in Southern Canada. We see that project needs a substantial amount of additional research and certainly consultation before we're able to move forward. And most importantly, it needs some higher gas prices, so we're going to continue to work it. It's obviously pretty exciting to play with that kind of resource in place. So I don't think you'll see us massively drilling in Mist Mountain next year though.

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Leo Mariani with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Leo Mariani with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Want to get a sense of if you guys have come up with sort of an approximate of well inventory of projects in the Granite Wash at this point in time?
componenttext: Want to get a sense of if you guys have come up with sort of an approximate of well inventory of projects in the Granite Wash at this point in time?

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have a substantial inventory. And I can tell you that the inventory is somewhat dynamic. We continue to move different wells to the top of the list but there's an excess of 1,000 locations that we know we have out there. So it's just a matter of which
componenttext: We have a substantial inventory. And I can tell you that the inventory is somewhat dynamic. We continue to move different wells to the top of the list but there's an excess of 1,000 locations that we know we have out there. So it's just a matter of which ones we're were going to drill first. Like I told you, we think we can keep about 10 rigs running. The only issues out there today have been access to frac equipment and that'll probably continue to be an issue.

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: And how many wells you think you can drill in a year with 10 rigs out there and what do those wells cost you, roughly, a piece to drill?
componenttext: And how many wells you think you can drill in a year with 10 rigs out there and what do those wells cost you, roughly, a piece to drill?

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're spending about somewhere in the $5 million range, sometimes it's $6 million, depends on how many times we frac these things. But one of the interesting piece we're were doing, we did do a dual lateral this year. We have not completed the second late
componenttext: We're spending about somewhere in the $5 million range, sometimes it's $6 million, depends on how many times we frac these things. But one of the interesting piece we're were doing, we did do a dual lateral this year. We have not completed the second lateral yet. But that could change our price structure on a per lateral basis substantially. We will complete the second lateral early next year, and then we'll some good feel for where that can go. So 10 rigs we can drill a well of roughly every month. So if you have 10 rigs running, you could drill 100 wells roughly.

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of when you guys are talking about in Egypt, it sounds like your Phase 2 with Faghur, when you start up here, I guess it already has. So trying to get a sense of what the incremental volumes are going to be from that Phase 2?
componenttext: In terms of when you guys are talking about in Egypt, it sounds like your Phase 2 with Faghur, when you start up here, I guess it already has. So trying to get a sense of what the incremental volumes are going to be from that Phase 2?

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Phase 1 was completed back in May and that was the initial early production facility that ended up 20,000 barrels of oil per day. That was completed on scheduled. Phase 2, which we're ramping up an additional 20,000 to 40,000 which was complete at the end
componenttext: Phase 1 was completed back in May and that was the initial early production facility that ended up 20,000 barrels of oil per day. That was completed on scheduled. Phase 2, which we're ramping up an additional 20,000 to 40,000 which was complete at the end of September, and that is what's currently producing. We have a Phase 3, which is really to capture the 35 million to 40 million cubic feet of gas per day that's associated with oil. And that would be complete probably in the second quarter of 2011.

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just want to clarify one of the comments I thought I heard in the call. Did you guys say that your thoughts,  your North Sea Forties production would be in the low 60,000 barrel a day range for the next, roughly, three years. Is that right?
componenttext: I just want to clarify one of the comments I thought I heard in the call. Did you guys say that your thoughts,  your North Sea Forties production would be in the low 60,000 barrel a day range for the next, roughly, three years. Is that right?

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to get a sense on the Permian. Kind of where you guys thought you were in terms of evaluating  some of these new horizontal plays out There. Is Kind of early days for you? Have you done some test wells?  Can you give us a sense of kind of wh
componenttext: I just wanted to get a sense on the Permian. Kind of where you guys thought you were in terms of evaluating  some of these new horizontal plays out There. Is Kind of early days for you? Have you done some test wells?  Can you give us a sense of kind of where you are there?

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I gave you a few examples of some things we've done and I think, we have tested eight different horizons out there with horizontal wells already this year. And we're finding some interesting results. I got to tell you, I'm not ready to share all of
componenttext: Well, I gave you a few examples of some things we've done and I think, we have tested eight different horizons out there with horizontal wells already this year. And we're finding some interesting results. I got to tell you, I'm not ready to share all of that information because was obviously some of that's critical as we gather up acreage around our successes. But we have had good results we've shared with you, a somewhat surprising benefit horizontal in these old water plugs. We'll just continue to be amazed. We're drilling wells that come in at 400 barrels a day on fields that have been 60, 70 years old and had been water flooded and on 10-acre spacing. So we think the potential for horizontal drilling in the Permian is just unbelievable, really.

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Looking at production real quick. I think you guys were just talking about getting to just over 775,000 barrels a day in December. I guess, if i just kind of think about the math from a high level, that you guys are adding somewhere around 140,000 barrels
componenttext: Looking at production real quick. I think you guys were just talking about getting to just over 775,000 barrels a day in December. I guess, if i just kind of think about the math from a high level, that you guys are adding somewhere around 140,000 barrels a day from acquisition and producing about 660,000 barrels a day a little bit over that I guess in the third quarter. If I add those two up gets me closer to 800,000. Is there any declines between that 800,000 and the 775,000? Maybe your Gulf volume is expected to drop a little bit or can you provide any color on that?

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: We don't anticipate to shoot the gun all the time. So we're comfortable with 775,000 right now.
componenttext: We don't anticipate to shoot the gun all the time. So we're comfortable with 775,000 right now.

headline: Apache Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
